Well, sorry folks, the Nolans seem to talk the talk but they can't walk the walk. The "dramatic" content of this film is barely above that of a romantic comedy. It relies too heavily on time paradoxes but doesn't really give us the psychological background of the characters, as to why they do what they do. Some cliché shots: explanation of the worm hole is exactly the same as in Event horizon. The girl running after the car of the departing father, only to be held by another loved one, queue dramatic music- wow, I haven't seen that before. The "beings" (or us in the future) simplifying their reality so it suits our cognitive capacities-come on Matthew, you've done that movie already! The robots look like Monoliths from 2001. Well, if you're gonna be inspired by Kubrick, be inspired by the sheer emotional and psychological subtlety and precision that makes 2001 a masterpiece."Human nature" is a very easy answer to explain both all the evil and all the goodness that is going on. Yeah we have survival instinct, also compassion for our loved ones, which may come into conflict with the overall goal of our survival as species. So where are all these forced-tear-jerker scenes coming from? What else is new since 2001 or Solaris? Is that all there is to it? A movie with this much ambition and hype was supposed to be a milestone in the genre, but instead it is a faint copy, easily forgettable. What we've seen previously from these guys in films like The Following, Memento and also in Dark Knight, hell, even Inception, is that they really know how to create memorable characters with unique insight into their psychological background. None of that complexity is to be found in this movie. The characters are made from cardboard and they feel like repetitions of other sci- fi movie stereotypes. The dramatic substance of the movie, which is literally thrown to our faces every moment, does not live up to the quality of its' technical execution. Sure the visuals are great, but that's to be expected from a $169 million movie. Music is great too, though sometimes overused, but it's Hans Zimmer for crying out loud. What I enjoyed was the layout of the dystopic future, perhaps a little emphasis on how the world came to be that way would have made for a better and more plausible movie(don't even get me started on the absurd physics of this movie. good luck running from a black-hole).Simply put, this film is by no means a 9, and it simply doesn't qualify for the top250 (though of course there are many titles there which don't qualify even for the top875384).

I'm disappointed. Nolan failed to break out of his mold and make a truly challenging movie. This is one heck of a summer pop corn movie, I'll give it that. But it's not much more than that, and it has perhaps the worst sound design I've heard in 20 years. Nolan himself says in interviews that this is what he wanted -- really loud with dialog that's hard to hear. To make it "more immersive" apparently. But if I want immersive, I can go ride my pick of rides at an amusement park. What I want when I go to the theater is for the director to tell a story. And his crappy sound design gets in the way of his telling of his story. And the story is yet another variation on his favorite theme of recursion. Meh. Getting old Chris. Old. And by the end of the movie, so were the endless references to 2001. Sheesh.A good amusement park ride, yes it is. But it's still considerably below the bar set by Gravity last year.

Interstellar (2014) -I think it would be easy to call this the 2014 equivalent of '2001: A Space Odyssey' (1968), but this one actually has substance and a decent storyline and didn't bore me within the first five minutes. It does seem to make many references to that film too, whilst also having an early 'Star Trek' and 'Lost In Space' (Enterprise/Start of Earth's attempts to explore) vibe about it too.I liked the semi documentary style that they employed at the beginning, but I think that they could have used it more throughout as it would have broken up everything else.It was also well paced to start, but did seem to drag after a while and I think that the ending could have wrapped a bit quicker.I personally might have written out the son to save a bit of time, as he didn't add much to it at all and that could have shortened it by about 15 minutes. I don't mind an epic and I'm happy to sit and watch 3 hour films as long as it's necessary and not just missed opportunities in editing or story boarding.Regarding the actors, someone needs to teach Mr McConaughey about diction, but apart from his drawl that was entirely incoherent at times (Thank the Lord for Subtitles) he did a good job and probably stood out amongst a talented cast that do a good job, but didn't give us anything Oscar worthy otherwise.Although HE did give something pretty Oscar worthy in 'The Martian' (2015) and I suppose that this film shows us what would have happened if Maertt Day-Man had never survived on Mars, I would say that this was only an average performance on his part.He was a bit too similar to his Ripley character from 'The Talented Mr Ripley' (1999) and his traits all seemed a bit obvious, because of that.Michael Caine and John Lithgow are worth noting too, but didn't get a huge amount of screen time to warrant any rapture.As for the special effects, although I don't generally advocate overusing CGI, I think that they could have spared a little more for TARS, etc. At times they looked like something from 1960's 'Doctor Who' and made of the same cheap foil covered cardboardy materials too. I assume that they were a nod to the random slabs in '2001: A Space Odyssey'?I don't have time to read all of the trivia about the science of the film, it's way beyond my failed GCSE science grade anyway, but some of it seems a bit unlikely. That didn't diminish the story it's telling though and I don't think that you need to know quantum mechanics to enjoy it.I did find it curious that it's not an established work of fiction or even based on an article or short story. It's very well thought out, which I don't find to be the case that often for stories of this kind that are purely constructs of the film industry.In some ways you could say that the story has parts that are reflected in 'Ghostbusters: Afterlife' (2021). The house in the middle of nowhere, the warning sounds and so on. At least it certainly reminded me of that.I think like some of the other "Epic" films - 'Forrest Gump' (1994) for example, it's one to tune in to no more frequently than every 5 years or so, to enable you to find newness in it and satisfaction of a few hours well spent.There are better sci-fi's out there for my tastes, but I can see that this was well done and could easily become a cult classic.769.08/1000.

If you are one of those people that thought Inception was a really good movie and it made a whole lot of sense, then stop reading this review; you will not agree with it.Interstellar is a movie that I have been waiting for a long time, ever since they released teasers and trailers and a lot of science blogs started talking about it. I held myself away from such discussions, though, because I wanted to have an open mind when I watched it. My verdict: really well done movie that made absolutely no sense, in any number of dimensions. People said that it was inspiring; if it inspires anyone, that's good, but don't come crying to me when they come back disappointed that they cannot hear the symphonic music and the BWAAAAANG in space, like they expected it.I really don't want to spoil anything, so I will stop here. It took a mere 15 minutes for me to start gritting my teeth and it only became worse as time went by for the entire three hour length of this space sham. Prepare yourselves for Nolan's attempt at a Space Odyssey 2001, only with more special effects and no understanding of science whatsoever. It hits all the right emotional buttons and, indeed, if you have the intelligence of a dog, you will love this film at the level that they are so loving towards their masters.Matthew McConaughey is brilliant in his role, all the supporting actors are great, visual effects are good, even if unnecessarily over the top, all the little details are well taken care of... all except a script that makes any sense beyond "Oh, love, boo hoo!".Bottom line: my head hurts with angry disappointment. I am at fault for expecting so much from this movie. Another eye candy ego trip from a director that thinks too highly of himself.

This is a movie that I remember seeing in the theater. I believe it was with my buddy of Robert. He's a big Christopher Nolan fan and at that point, I liked everything from him that I had seen. This is one that I put on a list of ones that I wanted to revisit as it blew me away. Jaime and I watched this as part of the Internet Movie Database Top 100 movies poster.What I think makes this movie work the best is the fact that it is set in the future, but it is so grounded that you notice subtle things before realizing it. Cooper (Matthew McConaughey) is a former pilot and engineer who now is a farmer. His goal was to go into space, but the missions were abandoned. Earth is in a tough spot. It needs farmers as people are starving. In the process, plants are dying out and humans are over farming. It is taking all of the nutrients out of the soil.Cooper lives with his daughter Murph (Mackenzie Foy) and son, Tom (Timothée Chalamet). Also living with them is Cooper's father-in-law of Donald (John Lithgow). Murph is convinced that there is a ghost in her room. Cooper wants her to look at it logically. He realizes there is a presence which leads to a secret base. Inside of it are the remnants of NASA. Professor Brand (Michael Caine) is working on a team with his daughter, Brand (Anne Hathaway), Doyle (Wes Bentley), Williams(William Devane) and Romilly (David Gyasi). This is just to name a few.The goal is finding a new planet to move humanity to. They've discovered a wormhole by Saturn. Teams have already been sent. They are supposed to relay information back to Earth. It seems like things have gone wrong. The last-ditch effort is to send this team up to figure out if any of the planets are viable. Cooper is asked to pilot the mission. This upsets his daughter of Murph. We see the ramifications years down the line when she grows up to be played by Jessica Chastain. Life on Earth is at the end, but will humanity survive?That is where I'm going to leave my recap and I should state that I left a lot out. This movie runs almost three hours. Surprisingly, it doesn't feel like it. I believe that Jaime and I watched this in two parts. The first section we were shocked to see that we only had an hour left. We were both tired though and that is partly contributed to our newborn daughter, Mackenzie.What I think helps the pacing is that we have a deep story. It is one that even if you're paying attention, you miss a lot. I remembered what the reveal was. Jaime thinks she saw part of this, but didn't think she saw it all the way through. There are sections that felt familiar. The beginning section though is Earth dying. I was telling her that this is based in fact. If memory serves, soybeans helps put nutrients back into the soil. That is why most farmers in the Midwest will plant them periodically. If they don't, there could be a reoccurrence of the dust bowl when the top soil was blown away. This is also why the Sahara Desert is growing. As the population on Earth grows, we could continue to get closer to what is happening here.There is a part of this as this like 2001: A Space Odyssey. They go through the wormhole and to a few different plants. All the while, we are seeing what is happening on Earth. There are also this almost documentary footage that is edited in. When I figured out how that factored into the ending, I loved it. This is just a well-made movie. The cinematography brings these things to life. I don't know if it is factual or not. Nolan does though so that makes me go with it. What I also want to include here is that we get the idea of time travel. It is handled in a different way which is something else I appreciate. There is CGI here, but you need it. It looks great as this had a budget that could do that for sure.I think that makes this work as well is the great cast. McConaughey, Hathaway and Chastain are listed as our leads. They are all good and it is movies like this that make you see why. I'm also going to give a lot of credit to Foy. She is a child here, but the emotions she shows is great. There is also Ellen Burstyn, Lithgow, Chalamet, Oyelowo, Collette Wolfe, Bentley, Devane, Josh Stewart, Casey Affleck and Matt Damon, to just name a few. There is more that I could add on top of it.Now this movie won't be for everyone. I think that it does great things. It isn't the first movie like this, as I've already laid out a classic that this borrows from. What I think this does better is frame a story around it. Being that this came out after, it needed to do something to set it apart. I believe this is my favorite Nolan movie. It is one that I'd say to not get discouraged if you don't understand it. It doesn't do a great job at explaining the science, which is quite complicated. Take what you can and it requires multiple viewings.My Rating: 9 out of 10.

After watching Interstellar for the second time it jumped 20 places on my all-time favorite movies from 20th to 1st. I don't know why Matthew McConaughey didn't win another Oscar for his absolute amazing performance; the guy really gives his all when he's on camera. The story isn't your typical, perfunctory alien/space movie but instead centers around how the current generation has the power to make or break the future depending on how they utilize their resources and how some humans tend to be so selfish when hard times come (dialogue at 28 minutes). Moreover, it really is the first movie that really explained the four dimensions of space and time to me in utterly breathtaking fashion. Nolan really managed to make astronomy interesting again and in a world where education is becoming undervalued, inspires us to grow and learn. The movie is filled to the brim with dialogues and lessons that everyone can learn from and understand. Hans Zimmer delivered possibly the greatest ever soundtrack of all time (goosebumps!) to complement the beautiful CGI and remarkable storytelling. Interstellar isn't a movie, its an experience. Unfortunately I cannot give it more than 10 stars because it absolutely does deserve higher.

Christopher Nolan's "Interstellar" is a cinematic masterpiece that delves deep into the realms of space exploration, human survival, and the unbreakable bonds of love. With its breathtaking visuals and a hauntingly beautiful score by Hans Zimmer, the film takes audiences on a journey that is as much about the vastness of the universe as it is about the intimate connections between a father and his daughter.Set in a dystopian future where Earth is dying, the narrative follows a group of astronauts, led by the former pilot Cooper (Matthew McConaughey), as they embark on a perilous mission through a wormhole near Saturn in search of a new home for humanity. The film beautifully juxtaposes the vast, cold expanse of space with the warmth of human emotions, making it a deeply moving experience.The scientific concepts, including black holes, time dilation, and the theory of relativity, are intricately woven into the plot, making "Interstellar" not just a visual spectacle but also a thought-provoking exploration of the mysteries of the universe. While some may argue that the film takes certain liberties with scientific accuracy, it's essential to remember that at its core, "Interstellar" is a work of fiction meant to entertain, inspire, and provoke thought.The performances are top-notch, with McConaughey delivering one of his career-best roles. Anne Hathaway, Jessica Chastain, and Michael Caine also shine in their respective roles, bringing depth and authenticity to their characters.However, what truly sets "Interstellar" apart is its emotional depth. The film's exploration of love, sacrifice, and the passage of time resonates deeply, making it a tear-jerker for many. The relationship between Cooper and his daughter Murph (played by Mackenzie Foy and later by Jessica Chastain) is the beating heart of the story, and their emotional reunion is one of the most touching moments in cinematic history.In conclusion, "Interstellar" is a grand, ambitious, and emotionally charged film that pushes the boundaries of storytelling and filmmaking. It's a testament to Nolan's genius that he can craft a narrative that is both epic in scale and deeply personal in emotion. A must-watch for anyone who appreciates cinema that challenges, entertains, and moves the soul.
I believe this is probably one of the most overrated movies ever. A "2001" wannabe, full of boring clichés and nonsense sci-fi. Probably the definition of the expression: over-promise, under-deliver.

What is with all the 10 star marks for this overhype disaster. I can suspend reality with ease, but this asks us to become blythering idiots. Flying around black holes by the seat of your pants and people are like, yeah that's the ticket. Give me a break. Besides that the actors are constantly crying or performing unbelievable acts against physics, is the annoying editing where they keep phasing out a scene into another totally unrelated scene. Mathew fearlessly flies us to from one galaxy to the next in search of a home. The audience, so easily impressed find it facsinating and can't wait to see Mathew worm his way out of the most massive tidal wave ever, only to navigate his ship into docking with an out of control mothership. Then ends behind a multi-dimensional bookshelf. THe crowd applauds like trained seal. Horrible Sci-Fi.
